docs.lead_paragraph: At the 150th-anniversary dinner of the British Medical Association two years ago the well-fed physicians who settled back for a speech by Prince Charles had a jolt. ''I would suggest that the whole imposing edifice of modern medicine, for all its breathtaking successes is, like the celebrated Tower of Pisa, slightly off balance,'' Charles said, departing from the royal family's policy of avoiding controversy. ''It is frightening how dependent on drugs we are all becoming and how easy it is for doctors to prescribe them as the universal panacea for our ills.'' The speech hit an exposed nerve. For several years anecdotal evidence and sporadic surveys had found a growing number of Britons rejecting conventional medicine or supplementing it with visits to chiropractors, acupuncturists and specialists in herbal treatment. The trend has accelerated since the speech, intensifying research on alternative medicines, spurring sales of related products and causing ferment in the profession. There has also been an upsurge of interest on the part of press and broadcasting, culminating in a rare in-depth interview granted by Prince Charles last summer to The Evening Standard, in which his interest in alternative medicine was spread across four pages.
